Can anyone here tell me why prices are higher when markets are controlled by monopolies? Remember that monopolies can not simply set prices as high as they want. How do monopolists determine how much to charge for a good? 
 
 What other negative economic side effects can you think of where monopolies exist? Do monopolies ever benefit the consumer?

in perfect competition, the market determines the price where the supply curve and the demand curve meet.
 
 in monopolies, since they have no competition and do not have to follow a market), do not set the price where supply (or marginal cost) equals demand (or marginal benefit). they produce at the quantity where marginal revenue meets marginal cost and set the price where the demand curve is at that specific quantity. (this sounds confusing, i wish i was able to draw a graph or something).
 
 monopolies are very inefficient because consumer and producer surplus is not maximized.

the only benefit of monopolies i'm aware of is that then every type of a given item is the same. So the benefit is compatability.
 
 i thought the deal about monopolies was they could set thier prices as high as they wanted to?
